comments.commentBody: Gee, Mr. Luettgen, I'd like to hear your views on Obama's predecessor, although I strain to determine whether his name is Bush or Cheney. Was that "leadership" that got thousands of dead GIs killed for a lie? Was that "leadership" that got the huge Medicare Part D giveaway to big pharma with no funding for it and has contributed trillions to our deficit? Was that "leadership" that gave huge no bid contracts to Halliburton? Was that "leadership" that had to outlaw photographs of flag draped coffins in order to try and escape responsibility for the absolute disaster in Iraq?  Or was that simple stupid cowboy thuggery?

Obama may not always be the best politician - although he did win two national elections - but his lack of political skills is not the reason for most of his failures. From the moment of his first election, Republicans have denied his legitimacy, often with barely disguised racism, and opposed him at every turn. Funny, they did that with Bill Clinton, too.

[You might notice that the Canadian-born Ted Cruz is running for president without a single "birther" rising to object.]

That is one of the two main reasons for his current political situation. The other is that America has two electorates: one, diverse and substantially liberal, dominates years divisible by four; the other, overwhelmingly white and conservative, dominates the off-years. Presto, Gridlock.

No amount of "leadership" could surmount this double whammy.

@Richard Luettgen: Can you honor Dubya for failing to democratize the ENTIRETY of the Middle East or failing to safeguard the ENTIRETY of the economy? Lest you forget, our most recent Republican president lied us into an unnecessary war in Iraq, which he then conducted with monumental incompetence, adding trillions to our nation's debts. The economy tanked under his stewardship, leaving a monumental mess for Obama to clean up. Gnash your teeth and use all the capital letters you want; your guy was a failure and ours was a success, especially when compared to his predecessor.

We should all remember what happened to Sen. Jay Billington Bulworth, in the end; and that it was his fault that it happened.

Because we’re tired of pointing out the myriad things he CAN’T do because of the tragedy of a lack of requisite political skills so monumental it’s positively Shakespearean … we honor him for his mouth. May as well honor Donald Trump, as his is so VERY much bigger.

The saddest reality for Barack Obama is that he probably WON’T hurt his party by a diminishing patience with all the misguided and hateful who won’t simply cave to his manifestly evident incandescence, because their own better judgment informs them that his policy preferences might be for the birds. The moving finger writes; and, having writ, moves on. He still holds the power of kings, so one must approach the throne with some care; but now the more rational among the liberati begin to gather around Hillary, while those markedly less so around Bernie. Attention has shifted to the future, and he’s rapidly becoming the past.

Since before 20 January 2009, I’ve been egging him on far more insistently than Maureen ever did to go to school on what it means to be a successful leader, and how leadership requires skills that were never natural to him but that he MUST develop. I’m done, too. Too late to make a difference any more.

So, I can’t honor him for reforming the ENTIRETY of our healthcare framework so it works, as he once promised to do. I’ll cave, too, and honor him merely for his mouth.
I tripled the sauce and it was way too much lemon! and need to put much more butter.

I'm not convinced Mr Trump's star is about to start its descent, I also don't agree that people will not see a serious presidential candidate when they look closely.  As an Independent voter with very liberal social views, but a sense of fiscal conservatism I see a definite appeal in Mr Trump and I am quite certain that I am not alone amongst the well educated who own their own businesses to do so.  The thing Mr Trump said that really struck a cord with me, is that it's easy to "spend other people's money," but if you have to make it yourself you look at it in a different way.  This is so true, politicians in charge are spending billions of tax payer money, but yet, most of them have never had any hand in creating wealth, as a matter of fact, most of the other presidential candidates are career politicians, dependent on donors and wealthy backers, whereas Mr Trump needs the approval of no-one sitting "behind the curtain" and what you see is what you get. There is an honesty and quite frankly a sense of decency to this, something you will not see in Hillary Clinton, whom (if anyone but Trump gets the Republican nomination) I would vote for in a heart beat.  If you think this sounds odd, go ahead and ask your registered Independent voter friends and you may be surprised at the cord Mr Trump is striking.
Maybe Sarah Palin should marry Donald Trump; they're the perfect "power couple."
Often you don't have to do anything to defeat carnival barkers like Donald Trump except wait for them to self-destruct.
Yep, it is amazing how social media allows anonymous comments from the kooks as they emerge from underneath their rocks.
Read the comments on Facebook. They will tell you more about the nature of the "average" voter than the NY Times readership.
Trump is a buffoon. Stop covering him.

Good judgement & discipline are extraordinarily important characteristics in a Presidential candidate. The ability to take on the most important issues and to remain focussed on those areas where one's leadership can make a difference is essential.
By lashing out at everyone and anything in sight diminishes the candidate and reduces him to a cartoon caricature of himself. For someone who proclaims himself to be so much smarter than the average guy, Mr. Trump has unwittingly exposed himself to be a clown and a fraud.
To denigrate a man who had the courage and the guts to serve in combat while Mr. Trump sat on his rump at the Wharton School while receiving a 4F deferment (for good measure) from the Family doctor is the height of stupidity and arrogance.
Mr. Trump...have you no shame? Mr. Trump......have you no brains?
Someone needs to capture Donald Trump, lock him up in a cell, and throw away the keys.  Then see what he says about being captured.

OMG, you pundits and commentators live in a echo chamber for nitwits! The republican base hates John McCain - but you knew that, right? The Donald just got 366,000+ likes on his latest post in just 5hours and millions in the fb community are ripping McCain relentlessly. I got more likes than every in my 7yr fb history on my comments on McCain tonight. You really need to open your fb account and check the Donald's page before writing nonsense. The more the GOP field attacks Trump, the more votes they will lose.
And more is the pity,  because he has been speaking important truths to those young men.
Francois: I don't think he needs the money as much as he needs the adulation.
No it wasn't just Hollywood. This behavior was everywhere and still exists in some holdout areas and sex industries where women do not and cannot speak out. They are criminals too, right?

This is Hollywood--the kind of things Cosby has done have been going on for years.  He's not the only one.  But what did him in was holding himself up as some stalwart of taste and decorum, going on about how young black men should behave better these days.  He was literally a man in a glass house throwing stones.  It was a young black comic who called him out on his hypocrisy.  When he continued to try to perform, I wondered why he was putting himself out on stage, and then it hit me-- he has a lot of people to pay off.  He needs money.

Senator McCain has served his country most of his life, in the military and in public service, whether you like his politics or not. Trump has served nothing and no one but himself his whole life. I liked Romney's response, that the difference between McCain and Trump is that Trump shot himself down! I also liked the quote of the devout lady in Iowa commenting about Trump, "I'm not sure he's really a born again Christian." I think not ma'am.

The war would have been shorter yet, with "heroes" like Trump who can't tell his left foot from his right, or to be fair can't "remember" which foot had a boo boo so serious he couldn't serve the country he now wants to lead.
The scary thing is the number of people on Twitter defending Trump and slamming John McCain.

Trump's stature in the GOP primary is magnified by the large number of candidates, and the relative low turnout in primary voting.

If each of the 17 GOP candidates had an equal share of support, at best that AVERAGE level of support would be just under 6%.

As long as there are 17 candidates, Trump's level of support doesn't have to be numerically high in overall terms, but only relative to that of his rivals.

There's no reason to believe, that I can see, that Trump's standing among the contenders, and his level of support, will in any way diminish, until the field of candidates begins to thin out.

Trump has all the money he needs to propel his message, unlike most of the other candidates, who must win or be winnowed in the first few contests.

I think Trump is here to stay, and may well chose to switch to an independent status when he likely does not attain the GOP nomination.

There is no reason for Trump to compromise and close ranks with the GOP down the road, since his candidacy is really only about getting Donald Trump in the white house.

I welcome the GOP voters having an opportunity to vote for a candidate who does support a "right to chose" and "universal health care", as many of them never get the chance.

Trump's presence will force the GOP field to answer policy issues they otherwise prefer to avoid.

Trump's xenophobia is unfortunate. But I never saw John McCain as very smart.
A boor is a boor is a boor.

Something good might come out of this. The Republican establishment might start getting tough and put the lid on Murdoch and FOX. That crowd is out of control and it's doing the party no favors, not to mention the country. Trump is great for FOX business and terrible, just devastating to the GOP.

Trump may have stepped over the line. One is not allowed to challenge John McCain's service record. If one does that person will be killed off. The problem is, Trump has a point. The point  will not be recognized by anyone, or even understood or believed by many. I think a good investigative reporter from the NYT should take a very close look at McCain's behavior when he was at the Hanoi Hilton compared to other prisoners that were there at the same time. Before everyone condemns Trump, it might be fair to check McCain out. I know that it is difficult but it probably should be done.

I cannot let this comment go unchallenged.

While I am at best ambivalent about John Mc Cain as a political figure (I voted for Obama 2x), the man is a worthy of honor and respect for his valorous service in the USN.

The wiki article, should you read it, negates all the half truths written above.

To summarize, McCain is highly intelligent, but was rebellious and ambivalent as a USN career was the family business. Nobody wants to be their dad at age 19.

Information given in exchange for medical care that saved his life (the man has a bum arm and his hair turned white from this experience) related the names of cities already bombed and the Green Bay Packers offensive line.

He was in solitary confinement for TWO YEARS. The signed confession was the result of aggressive torture administered every two hours that reinjured him to a inhumane degree.

The recalcitrance he showed at Annapolis served him well at the POW camp as he showed no obeisance to his captors.

Additionally, he declined an out of sequence repatriation due to his notoriety.

If i was ever in a foxhole, I would want this guy next to me.
Thanks for your service John Mc Cain!

Despite the NVA
Hey Donald: you're fired.
Cogent writing from Mr. Cohn, with well supported conclusions, about Sanders and now Trump.
After Trump's comments about McCain, RNC will require a no 3rd party run pledge for the debates. Trump will do a Perot.

I appreciate McCain's military service, though I believe "hero" status is too easily granted.  BUT he lost all credibility to claim "hero" status when he sold out and named Sarah Palin his VP candidate.
It is nice to know that the GOP actually has a bottom that below which, not even they will stomach.  The redheaded loud clown isn't so funny all of the sudden, eh?

He is the best qualified candidate to become POTUS.
Trump knows how to make America a better and safer nation.

What is the evidence for these statements? Your gut feeling? Do tell.
